bitcoin.main.ecdsa_raw_verify(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶
bitcoin.main.ecdsa_sign(msg, priv)[source]¶

The private key priv must be supplied in binary, not hex. Note: Compatibility issue: old bots will be confused by adifferent msg hashing algo; need to keep electrum_sig_hash, for now. A base64 encoded signature is returned.

bitcoin.main.ecdsa_verify(msg, sig, pub)[source]¶

The pubkey must be supplied in binary, not hex. The messages should not be pre-hashed. See the compatibility note to ecdsa_sign. True or False is returned.

bitcoin.main.electrum_sig_hash(message)[source]¶
bitcoin.main.get_version_byte(inp)[source]¶
bitcoin.main.hash160(string)[source]¶
bitcoin.main.hash_to_int(x)[source]¶
bitcoin.main.hex_to_b58check(inp, magicbyte=0)[source]¶
bitcoin.main.hexbin(func)[source]¶

To enable each function to ‘speak’ either hex or binary, requires that the decorated function’s final positional argument is a boolean flag, True for hex and False for binary.

bitcoin.main.legacy_ecdsa_sign_convert(dersig)[source]¶

A sadly necessary hack until all joinmarket bots are running secp256k1 code. pybitcointools message signatures (not transaction signatures) used an old signature format, basically: [27+y%2] || 32 byte r || 32 byte s, instead of DER. These two functions translate the new version into the old so that counterparty bots can verify successfully.

bitcoin.main.legacy_ecdsa_verify_convert(sig)[source]¶

See the documentation of legacy_ecdsa_sign_convert.

class bitcoin.ripemd.RIPEMD160(arg=None)[source]¶

Return a new RIPEMD160 object. An optional string argument may be provided; if present, this string will be automatically hashed.

ecdsa_recoverable_deserialize(ser_sig, rec_id)[source]¶
ecdsa_recoverable_serialize(recover_sig)[source]¶
ecdsa_serialize(raw_sig)[source]¶
ecdsa_serialize_compact(raw_sig)[source]¶
ecdsa_signature_normalize(raw_sig, check_only=False)[source]¶

Check and optionally convert a signature to a normalized lower-S form. If check_only is True then the normalized signature is not returned.

This function always return a tuple containing a boolean (True if not previously normalized or False if signature was already normalized), and the normalized signature. When check_only is True, the normalized signature returned is always None.

class bitcoin.secp256k1.PrivateKey(privkey=None, raw=True, flags=769, ctx=None)[source]¶

Bases: bitcoin.secp256k1.Base, bitcoin.secp256k1.ECDSA, bitcoin.secp256k1.Schnorr

deserialize(privkey_ser)[source]¶
ecdsa_sign(msg, raw=False, digest=<built-in function openssl_sha256>, randnonce=None)[source]¶
ecdsa_sign_recoverable(msg, raw=False, digest=<built-in function openssl_sha256>)[source]¶
schnorr_generate_nonce_pair(msg, raw=False, digest=<built-in function openssl_sha256>)[source]¶

Generate a nonce pair deterministically for use with schnorr_partial_sign.

schnorr_partial_sign(msg, privnonce, pubnonce_others, raw=False, digest=<built-in function openssl_sha256>)[source]¶

Produce a partial Schnorr signature, which can be combined using schnorr_partial_combine to end up with a full signature that is verifiable using PublicKey.schnorr_verify.

To combine pubnonces, use PublicKey.combine.

Do not pass the pubnonce produced for the respective privnonce; combine the pubnonces from other signers and pass that instead.

schnorr_sign(msg, raw=False, digest=<built-in function openssl_sha256>)[source]¶
serialize(compressed=True)[source]¶
set_raw_privkey(privkey)[source]¶
tweak_add(scalar)[source]¶

Add a 32 byte scalar to this private key and return the result, ensuring that the result is a valid private key also. Result is returned as 32 byte raw/scalar.

class bitcoin.secp256k1.PublicKey(pubkey=None, raw=False, flags=257, ctx=None)[source]¶

Bases: bitcoin.secp256k1.Base, bitcoin.secp256k1.ECDSA, bitcoin.secp256k1.Schnorr

Add a number of public keys together.
